question.title: Will Donald Trump Jr. be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if Donald Trump Jr. is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. All other candidates will resolve as **No**. This question is not restricted to the candidates currently mentioned; other options may be added in the future.

For this question, it is not relevant who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

metadata.chain_of_thought: To determine the likelihood of Donald Trump Jr. becoming the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election, we should consider several factors. Firstly, the current political landscape and the Republican Party's dynamics are crucial. Historically, the Republican Party has chosen nominees with significant experience in politics, such as governors or senators. Donald Trump Jr., although a prominent figure in the party due to his father's presidency, lacks direct experience in elected office. Secondly, it's essential to look at the current field of potential candidates. While the question does not restrict itself to currently mentioned candidates, it's likely that established politicians like governors, senators, or even former President Donald Trump himself might be more likely to secure the nomination. Lastly, considering the timeline, the question resolves on August 1, 2024, which is around the time the Republican National Convention typically takes place. This leaves enough time for the field of candidates to evolve, for primaries to take place, and for the party to coalesce around a nominee. Given these factors, while it's impossible to rule out any possibility entirely in the unpredictable world of U.S. politics, the lack of direct political experience by Donald Trump Jr. and the typical preferences of the Republican Party for nominees suggest that his chances, although not negligible due to his name recognition and influence, are less likely compared to more seasoned politicians.

question.title: [Metaculus] Will Joe Biden announce before July 15, 2024 that he will not accept the Democra...nomination for President?
question.body:

Resolves the same as the original on Metaculus.

(https://www.metaculus.com/questions/question_embed/25755/?theme=dark)Resolution criteria

This question will resolve as Yes if prior to 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, Joe Biden or his campaign makes a definitive, public, official announcement to the effect that Joe Biden will not seek and will not accept the nomination of his party for another term as President of the United States in the 2024 cycle.

To qualify for a Yes resolution, the statement must be unambiguous and conclusive: it should leave no room for the possibility that Biden would accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President of the United States in the 2024 election cycle.

If such a definitive statement is not made prior to 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, this question will resolve as No.

Fine print and additional background information can be found on Metaculus.

Once the original resolves, its resolution will be applied to this market automatically. Trustworthy-ish users are encouraged to resolve this market before then if the outcome is known and unambiguous. Feel free to ping @jskf to request early resolution or to report issues.

question.title: Will Biden remain President through end of July 2024?
question.body:
Resolves YES if Biden remains US President through the end of July 2024 (ET); resolves NO if he resigns, dies, or otherwise ceases to be President before then.

Temporary transfer of power under the 25th amendement (i.e. making his VP the Acting President) does not cause a YES resolution. (Acting President is different from President under the Constitution)

metadata.chain_of_thought: Based on Joe Biden's announced intention to run for re-election, the lack of public indications of severe health issues, and the current political climate, it is reasonable to conclude that he is likely to remain President through the end of July 2024.

It resolves NO if either condition is not met. Note that a temporary transfer of power under the 25th amendment does not affect the resolution of condition (b).

Considering the current information available, it is highly unlikely that Joe Biden will die before Saturday, July 27th, as there is no credible information suggesting any health issues or threats to his life. question.title: Will either of the following occur: (a) Joe Biden dies before Saturday, July 26th, 2024, or (b) Biden does not remain President through the end of July 2024?
question.body:
(a) Resolves YES if there is an official announcement of Joe Biden's death before market close at the end of Friday, July 26th, 2024. Otherwise, resolves NO.

(b) Resolves YES if Biden does not remain US President through the end of July 2024 (ET). This includes if he resigns, dies, or otherwise ceases to be President before then. Temporary transfer of power under the 25th amendment (i.e., making his VP the Acting President) does not cause a YES resolution, as Acting President is different from President under the Constitution.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To estimate the probability of either of the events (a) or (b) occurring, we need to consider the likelihood of Joe Biden's death or him not remaining President through the end of July 2024. First, let's consider event (a), Joe Biden's death before Saturday, July 26th, 2024. As of the knowledge cutoff in 2023, Joe Biden was 80 years old. According to the Social Security Administration's Actuarial Life Table, the probability of a person dying within a year at age 80 is approximately 14.2%. However, this probability is based on average life expectancy and does not take into account individual factors such as health conditions or lifestyle. Given that Joe Biden has been President since 2021 and has not shown any significant signs of poor health, it is reasonable to assume that his probability of death within the next year is lower than the average. However, it is still a possibility, and we should assign a non-zero probability to this event. Now, let's consider event (b), Biden not remaining President through the end of July 2024. This event includes the possibility of Biden resigning, dying, or otherwise ceasing to be President. While it is difficult to estimate the probability of Biden resigning or being removed from office, we can consider the historical precedent of Presidents serving out their terms. According to a study by the Pew Research Center, since World War II, only one President (Richard Nixon) has resigned from office. Given the low historical precedent for Presidential resignations or removals, it is reasonable to assign a low probability to this event. However, we should still consider the possibility of Biden's health declining or other unforeseen circumstances that could lead to his removal from office. Taking into account both events (a) and (b), we can estimate the overall probability of either event occurring. Assuming a probability of 5% for event (a) (lower than the average life expectancy due to Biden's apparent good health) and a probability of 1% for event (b) (based on historical precedent), we can calculate the overall probability as follows: Probability(event (a) or event (b)) = Probability(event (a)) + Probability(event (b)) - Probability(both events). Since the events are not mutually exclusive (Biden's death would also result in him not remaining President), we need to subtract the probability of both events occurring to avoid double-counting. Assuming that the probability of both events occurring is negligible (i.e., Biden's death is not directly related to his removal from office), we can simplify the calculation: Probability(event (a) or event (b)) ≈ Probability(event (a)) + Probability(event (b)) = 5% + 1% = 6%. Therefore, based on these estimates, the probability of either event (a) or event (b) occurring is approximately 6%.

question.title: Will Donald Trump be removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment?
question.body:
This question will resolve as "Yes" if, *on* July 15, 2024:

Donald Trump has been officially removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office (President, Senate, House of Representatives) under the grounds of Section 3 of the 14th Amendment.

The removal or block is confirmed through official state government announcements, court decisions, legal documentation, or credible media reports. Speculative reports, opinion pieces, or unofficial announcements will not suffice for resolution.

The question will resolve as "No" if these conditions are not met as of July 15, 2024.

Note: The question does not account for legal battles, appeals, or subsequent reversals that might occur *after* the mentioned date. It strictly pertains to whether Donald Trump has been removed from any state's primary election ballot for a federal office under the specified grounds as of July 15, 2024. If Trump is removed or blocked from a ballot and then reinstated, such that as of July 15th he is not removed or blocked from any ballot, the question resolves negatively.

metadata.chain_of_thought: This question is asking whether Donald Trump will be removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment by July 15, 2024. To answer this question, we need to consider the likelihood of such an event occurring. Section 3 of the 14th Amendment, also known as the Disqualification Clause, states that no person shall be a Senator or Representative in Congress, or elector of President and Vice President, or hold any office, civil or military, under the United States, or under any State, who, having previously taken an oath to support the Constitution of the United States, has engaged in insurrection or rebellion against the same, or given aid or comfort to the enemies thereof. In order for Donald Trump to be removed or blocked from the primary election ballot under this clause, there would need to be evidence that he has engaged in insurrection or rebellion against the United States, or given aid or comfort to its enemies. While there have been various controversies and criticisms surrounding Trump's presidency, there is no clear evidence to suggest that he has engaged in such activities. Furthermore, even if there were evidence of such activities, the process of removing someone from the ballot under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment would likely be complex and contentious, involving legal challenges and potentially lengthy court proceedings. Given the timeframe specified in the question, it seems unlikely that such a process could be completed by July 15, 2024. Therefore, based on the available information and the requirements of Section 3 of the 14th Amendment, it seems unlikely that Donald Trump will be removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office under this clause by July 15, 2024.

question.title: Will Donald Trump be removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment?
question.body:
This question will resolve as "Yes" if, *on* July 15, 2024:

Donald Trump has been officially removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office (President, Senate, House of Representatives) under the grounds of Section 3 of the 14th Amendment.

The removal or block is confirmed through official state government announcements, court decisions, legal documentation, or credible media reports. Speculative reports, opinion pieces, or unofficial announcements will not suffice for resolution.

The question will resolve as "No" if these conditions are not met as of July 15, 2024.

Note: The question does not account for legal battles, appeals, or subsequent reversals that might occur *after* the mentioned date. It strictly pertains to whether Donald Trump has been removed from any state's primary election ballot for a federal office under the specified grounds as of July 15, 2024. If Trump is removed or blocked from a ballot and then reinstated, such that as of July 15th he is not removed or blocked from any ballot, the question resolves negatively.

metadata.chain_of_thought: The question revolves around whether Donald Trump will be removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment by July 15, 2024. To answer this question, we must consider the political and legal landscape surrounding Trump's eligibility for federal office. Section 3 of the 14th Amendment, also known as the Disqualification Clause, states that no person shall be a senator or representative in Congress, or elector of president and vice president, or hold any office, civil or military, under the United States or under any state, who, having previously taken an oath to support the Constitution, has engaged in insurrection or rebellion against the United States, or given aid or comfort to its enemies. There have been ongoing debates and discussions about whether Trump's actions, particularly those related to the January 6, 2021, storming of the U.S. Capitol, could be considered an insurrection or rebellion under the Disqualification Clause. However, as of now, there is no clear indication that any state has officially removed or blocked Trump from their primary election ballot under this clause. Given the complexity of the legal process and the fact that the question specifically requires official confirmation through state government announcements, court decisions, legal documentation, or credible media reports, it is challenging to predict with certainty whether Trump will be removed or blocked from any state's primary election ballot by July 15, 2024. However, considering the ongoing investigations, lawsuits, and political tensions surrounding Trump, it is possible that some states might attempt to remove or block him from their primary election ballots under the Disqualification Clause. Nevertheless, the probability of this happening is difficult to estimate, and it largely depends on various factors, including the outcome of ongoing legal battles, the actions of state governments, and the political climate in the United States.

question.title: Will at least 20 House/Senate Democrats sign a public letter opposing the plan to virtually nominate Biden early?
question.body:
Context from Politico:

Dozens of House Democrats are organizing a plan to speak out against their own party’s effort to seal President Joe Biden’s nomination sooner than originally planned, which they argue stifles the intense ongoing debate about his candidacy, according to a lawmaker involved in the effort.

A drafted letter, circulated by Rep. Jared Huffman (D-Calif.) and obtained by POLITICO, offers the first public signal from Democrats since the weekend’s attempted assassination on former President Donald Trump that scores of their own members remain deeply unsettled about the future of Biden’s candidacy.

“It’s a really bad move by the DNC. Somebody thinks it’s a clever way to lock down debate and I guess by dint of sheer force, achieve unity, but it doesn’t work that way,” Huffman said in an interview. He declined to confirm the existence of a letter.

This market resolves YES if a public letter opposing the early nomination plan is signed by at least 20 House Members or Senators who caucus with the Democratic Party before market close at the end of Sunday, July 21st. 

Multiple such letters with a combined total of 20 lawmaker's signatures would also be sufficient to resolve this market to YES. 

If these criteria are not met by market close, this market resolves NO.

metadata.chain_of_thought: The question is asking whether at least 20 House/Senate Democrats will sign a public letter opposing the plan to virtually nominate Biden early. According to the context from Politico, dozens of House Democrats are organizing a plan to speak out against their own party's effort to seal President Joe Biden's nomination sooner than originally planned. A drafted letter, circulated by Rep. Jared Huffman (D-Calif.), has been obtained by POLITICO, and Huffman has expressed his opposition to the early nomination plan. While Huffman declined to confirm the existence of a letter, the fact that a drafted letter has been circulated and that Huffman has spoken out against the plan suggests that there is significant opposition to the early nomination plan among House Democrats. Additionally, the fact that the market resolves YES if a public letter opposing the early nomination plan is signed by at least 20 House Members or Senators who caucus with the Democratic Party before market close at the end of Sunday, July 21st, suggests that the market is expecting a significant number of Democrats to sign the letter. Based on this information, I believe that it is likely that at least 20 House/Senate Democrats will sign a public letter opposing the plan to virtually nominate Biden early.

question.title: Will both of the following occur: (1) At least 20 House/Senate Democrats sign a public letter opposing the plan to virtually nominate Biden early (2) 10 or more Democratic Senators call for Biden to drop out before July 20?
question.body:
(1) Context from Politico: Dozens of House Democrats are organizing a plan to speak out against their own party’s effort to seal President Joe Biden’s nomination sooner than originally planned, which they argue stifles the intense ongoing debate about his candidacy, according to a lawmaker involved in the effort. A drafted letter, circulated by Rep. Jared Huffman (D-Calif.) and obtained by POLITICO, offers the first public signal from Democrats since the weekend’s attempted assassination on former President Donald Trump that scores of their own members remain deeply unsettled about the future of Biden’s candidacy. “It’s a really bad move by the DNC. Somebody thinks it’s a clever way to lock down debate and I guess by dint of sheer force, achieve unity, but it doesn’t work that way,” Huffman said in an interview. He declined to confirm the existence of a letter. This market resolves YES if a public letter opposing the early nomination plan is signed by at least 20 House Members or Senators who caucus with the Democratic Party before market close at the end of Sunday, July 21st. If these criteria are not met by market close, this market resolves NO.

question.title: Will OpenAI's ChatGPT be generally available in the European Union on June 30, 2024?
question.body:
The question resolves as **YES** if [ChatGPT](chat.openai.com) is generally available in the EU on June 30, 2024, and **NO** otherwise.

"Generally available" here means that the default state for people in the EU is that they can access it without a VPN (possibly requiring paying for it.) If unavailable in certain EU countries (as was the case in Italy in early 2023), or unavailable to (for example) minors, this will still resolve positively, assuming at least >50% of the population can use it.

"ChatGPT" here refers to the general web interface (not the API) for interacting with GPT models. Still resolves positively if the name or website has changed, as long as OpenAI's service is substantially the same (entering queries to systems based on Large Language Models).

metadata.chain_of_thought: The question is asking about the general availability of OpenAI's ChatGPT in the European Union on June 30, 2024. To answer this question, we need to consider several factors, including the current availability of ChatGPT in the EU, any potential regulatory or legal issues that may affect its availability, and OpenAI's plans for expanding its services. Currently, ChatGPT is available in some EU countries, but its availability is limited due to regulatory concerns. For example, in early 2023, ChatGPT was unavailable in Italy due to concerns about data protection and privacy. However, OpenAI has been working to address these concerns and has made efforts to expand its services to more EU countries. In terms of regulatory issues, the EU has implemented several regulations that affect the availability of AI-powered services like ChatGPT. question.title: Will a group of at least 5 named Dem House Members or US Senators pressure Biden to drop out before July 20th?
question.body:
Politico reports:

Two safe-seat members have already publicly urged Biden out. Two of the most endangered Democrats told local news outlets they’ve already written off Biden’s chances to win in November.

Behind the scenes, things are even more frenzied. There are multiple drafts of letters circulating among House Democrats and at least one would call on Biden to end his campaign, according to five people familiar with the efforts.

This market resolves YES if a group of at least five named Democratic Party US House Members/US Senators work together to ask Joe Biden to consider ending his 2024 re-election campaign, or to urge him to do so, before Saturday July 20th (Pacific Time).

This could be by signing a letter like what is reported above, but it could also be in another form such as a group speaking with Biden in person and collectively asking him to drop out.

This market requires that all five individuals be part of the same group message. Five people separately telling reporters they think Biden should drop out is not sufficient for a YES resolution.

Reports of any number of unnamed democrats writing to Biden and asking him to step aside will not satisfy this market's criteria unless at least 5 qualifying names are later made public before this market's end date. In any ambiguous cases where such names are reported but not confirmed beyond a reasonable doubt, this market will err towards resolving NO. 

If these criteria are not met before July 20th, this market resolves NO.

The Politico report suggests that there is already some momentum behind this effort, with two safe-seat members publicly urging Biden out and multiple drafts of letters circulating among House Democrats. However, it's unclear whether these efforts will coalesce into a group of at least 5 named individuals working together to ask Biden to end his campaign. There are a few factors that suggest a YES resolution is possible. Firstly, the Politico report suggests that there is a sense of urgency among Democrats, with some members already writing off Biden's chances to win in November. This could create a sense of momentum behind efforts to pressure Biden to drop out. Secondly, the fact that multiple drafts of letters are circulating among House Democrats suggests that there is a coordinated effort underway. However, there are also some factors that suggest a NO resolution is possible. Firstly, it's unclear whether the efforts to pressure Biden to drop out will be successful in recruiting at least 5 named individuals. While there may be some Democrats who are willing to speak out against Biden, it's possible that others may be more reluctant to do so. Secondly, the market requires that all 5 individuals be part of the same group message, which could be a high bar to clear. Overall, I think that a YES resolution is possible, but it's not a certainty. I would estimate the probability of a YES resolution at around 0.4, reflecting the uncertainty and ambiguity surrounding the efforts to pressure Biden to drop out.

question.title: Will Deadpool & Wolverine have biggest opening weekend ever for R-rated movie? [ahead of Deadpool I & II, It, Joker]

Analysts are projecting a huge opening weekend for "Deadpool x Wolverine" crossover movie.
https://deepnewz.com/movies/deadpool-wolverine-set-record-360m-global-opening-weekend-biggest-r-rated-debut

"""

Domestically, the film is expected to debut with $160 million to $170 million, making it the biggest R-rated opening of all-time.

"""

[image]The record for biggest opening weekend for an R-rated movie is the original Deadpool at $284.5M ($152.2M domestic).

https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/movies/movie-news/box-office-deadpool-makes-history-865143/

[image]
Will the new movie top these marks? It will probably be close...

To clarify on resolution...

-> AND the Hollywood Reporter (or equivalent publication) reports it as the record for an R-rated movie release

In other words the BoxOfficeMojo numbers should be seen as unofficial until there's confirmation in the Hollywood press. And the number we shoot for is >$284.5M internationally... this weekend

question.title: Will Donald Trump be removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment?
question.body:
This question will resolve as "Yes" if, *on* July 15, 2024:

Donald Trump has been officially removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office (President, Senate, House of Representatives) under the grounds of Section 3 of the 14th Amendment.

The removal or block is confirmed through official state government announcements, court decisions, legal documentation, or credible media reports. Speculative reports, opinion pieces, or unofficial announcements will not suffice for resolution.

The question will resolve as "No" if these conditions are not met as of July 15, 2024.

Note: The question does not account for legal battles, appeals, or subsequent reversals that might occur *after* the mentioned date. It strictly pertains to whether Donald Trump has been removed from any state's primary election ballot for a federal office under the specified grounds as of July 15, 2024. If Trump is removed or blocked from a ballot and then reinstated, such that as of July 15th he is not removed or blocked from any ballot, the question resolves negatively.

metadata.chain_of_thought: The question revolves around whether Donald Trump will be removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment by July 15, 2024. To assess this, we need to consider the political and legal landscape. Section 3 of the 14th Amendment, also known as the Disqualification Clause, prohibits individuals who have engaged in insurrection or rebellion against the United States from holding federal office. The clause has been used in the past to disqualify individuals from public office, but its application to a former president is unprecedented. There have been efforts by some lawmakers and legal experts to invoke Section 3 to disqualify Trump from future federal office due to his alleged role in the January 6, 2021, storming of the U.S. Capitol. However, the process of disqualifying a candidate under Section 3 is complex and would likely involve legal challenges and potential court battles. Given the timeframe of the question (by July 15, 2024), it is uncertain whether any state would be able to complete the necessary legal proceedings to officially remove or block Trump from the primary election ballot under Section 3. The legal process can be lengthy, and it's possible that any attempts to disqualify Trump might not be resolved by the specified date. Additionally, it's worth noting that the question does not account for legal battles, appeals, or subsequent reversals that might occur after the mentioned date. This means that even if Trump is removed or blocked from a ballot and then reinstated, the question would resolve negatively if he is not removed or blocked as of July 15, 2024. Considering these factors, while there is a possibility that Trump could be removed or blocked from a state's primary election ballot under Section 3, the complexity of the legal process and the timeframe of the question make it uncertain. Therefore, I estimate the probability of the question resolving YES as follows:

metadata.chain_of_thought: To estimate the probability of this question resolving YES, let's break it down into two parts: (a) Biden remaining President through July 2024 and (b) Trump being removed from any primary election ballot under the 14th Amendment by July 15, 2024. For part (a), it's difficult to predict with certainty, but historically, the President of the United States has a relatively low rate of turnover due to resignation, death, or other reasons. As of my knowledge cutoff, there is no indication that Biden plans to resign or is in poor health. Therefore, I would estimate the probability of Biden remaining President through July 2024 as relatively high, around 0.8-0.9. For part (b), the 14th Amendment's Section 3, also known as the Disqualification Clause, has been invoked in the past to bar individuals from holding federal office. Given the political polarization and the fact that Trump has already announced his candidacy for the 2024 presidential election, it's unclear whether any state would successfully remove him from the primary election ballot under the 14th Amendment by July 15, 2024. I would estimate the probability of this event occurring as relatively low, around 0.1-0.2. Since the question resolves YES if either condition is met, we can use the formula for the probability of the union of two events: P(A  B) = P(A) + P(B) - P(A  B). Assuming independence between the two events, P(A  B) is approximately equal to P(A) × P(B). Therefore, the estimated probability of the question resolving YES is: P(YES) = P(Biden remains President) + P(Trump removed from ballot) - P(Biden remains President  Trump removed from ballot) = 0.85 + 0.15 - (0.85 × 0.15) = 0.85 + 0.15 - 0.1275 = 0.8725

question.title: Facing Joe Biden instead of a generic Democrat, will Trump gain at least 3% among Manifold respondents?
question.body:
There are two Manifold polls posted, which both close on July 6.  One of the polls asks Manifold respondents to vote with Joe Biden on a hypothetical ballot, and another asks respondents to vote with a generic Democrat on the hypothetical ballot.

@/SteveSokolowski/1-of-2-given-these-choices-who-woul@/SteveSokolowski/2-of-2-given-these-choices-who-woul 

Public opinion polls consistently show Joe Biden losing to Donald Trump outside the margin of error, but every other Democrat hypothetically surveyed polls ahead or within the margin of error.  Are Manifold respondents representative of the general public?

This market will resolve YES if the percentage of votes for Donald Trump in poll 1 exceeds that in poll 2 by 3% or more when both polls close.

The formula for determining the percentage of votes for Trump is (Trump / (Trump + (the Democrat in the question) + Someone else)).  The answer is YES if this formula for poll 1 - the formula for poll 2 >= 0.03.  Otherwise, it is NO.

The polls and this question will never resolve N/A, and will remain open until the close time no matter what.

question.title: Will Biden be declared incapacitated under the 25th Amendment Section 4 before August?
question.body:
Resolves YES if the Vice President and a majority of the Cabinet (or other relevant body) invokes Section 4 of the 25th Amendment to formally declare that "the President is unable to discharge the powers and duties of his office" and cause the Vice President to serve as Acting President, before August 2024 (Eastern time).

The duration of the incapacity does not matter for this question.

Biden exiting the office of the Presidency by death, resignation, etc does not count. Biden invoking section 3 of the 25th amendment does not count.

Context: GOP lawmaker asks Merrick Garland to invoke 25th Amendment to remove Biden from office

metadata.chain_of_thought: The question revolves around whether President Biden will be declared incapacitated under the 25th Amendment Section 4 before August 2024. To assess this probability, we need to consider the context and the conditions required for such a declaration. The 25th Amendment Section 4 states that the Vice President and a majority of the Cabinet can declare the President unable to discharge the powers and duties of his office, leading to the Vice President serving as Acting President. This is a significant and rare measure that requires substantial evidence of the President's incapacitation. Given the current political climate and the context provided, there is no concrete evidence to suggest that President Biden is incapacitated or that the Vice President and a majority of the Cabinet are considering invoking Section 4. The GOP lawmaker's request to Merrick Garland to invoke the 25th Amendment is not a formal declaration and does not indicate a consensus among the Cabinet or the Vice President. Moreover, the 25th Amendment is a serious constitutional mechanism that is not typically used for political gain or as a means to remove a President from office without clear evidence of incapacitation. The threshold for invoking Section 4 is high, and it is unlikely that the Vice President and a majority of the Cabinet would take such a drastic measure without compelling evidence. Therefore, based on the current information and the high threshold required for invoking Section 4, I estimate the probability of President Biden being declared incapacitated under the 25th Amendment Section 4 before August 2024 as low.

question.title: Will Scotland hold an official, sanctioned referendum on independence before May 3, 2024?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if there is a referendum held in Scotland regarding Scotland's independence from the United Kingdom, and this referendum is held before May 3, 2024.  This referendum may be an "advisory" referendum; that is, it is not necessary for the referendum to have any legally binding effect.

It shall not be deemed resolved by a “wildcat” or “Catalan” style of referendum where the UK government has declined permission for the vote, nor by a vote organised by civil society institutions. A referendum must be deemed to have the consent of the London government

metadata.chain_of_thought: The question of whether Scotland will hold an official, sanctioned referendum on independence before May 3, 2024, is complex and depends on various political factors. The Scottish National Party (SNP) has been pushing for a second independence referendum, but the UK government has been reluctant to grant permission. In 2021, the SNP won a majority in the Scottish Parliament, which they claimed gave them a mandate to hold a referendum. However, the UK government has maintained that it will not grant permission for a referendum without a clear consensus on the issue. In recent months, there have been indications that the UK government may be willing to consider a referendum, but only if certain conditions are met. Given these developments, it is possible that a referendum could be held before May 3, 2024, but it is far from certain. The UK government's position on the issue remains unclear, and it is possible that they may continue to block a referendum.

question.title: Will Donald Trump be removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment?
question.body:
This question will resolve as "Yes" if, *on* July 15, 2024:

Donald Trump has been officially removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office (President, Senate, House of Representatives) under the grounds of Section 3 of the 14th Amendment.

The removal or block is confirmed through official state government announcements, court decisions, legal documentation, or credible media reports. Speculative reports, opinion pieces, or unofficial announcements will not suffice for resolution.

The question will resolve as "No" if these conditions are not met as of July 15, 2024.

Note: The question does not account for legal battles, appeals, or subsequent reversals that might occur *after* the mentioned date. It strictly pertains to whether Donald Trump has been removed from any state's primary election ballot for a federal office under the specified grounds as of July 15, 2024. If Trump is removed or blocked from a ballot and then reinstated, such that as of July 15th he is not removed or blocked from any ballot, the question resolves negatively.

metadata.chain_of_thought: This question revolves around whether Donald Trump will be removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment by July 15, 2024. To assess the probability of this event, we need to consider several factors: 1. Legal Basis: Section 3 of the 14th Amendment, also known as the Disqualification Clause, prohibits individuals who have engaged in insurrection or rebellion against the United States from holding federal office. The application of this clause to Donald Trump would depend on legal interpretations and actions taken by state governments or courts. 2. Political Climate: The political climate in the United States is highly polarized, which could influence decisions regarding Trump's eligibility. However, the question specifically pertains to actions taken under the legal framework of Section 3, not political opinions or popularity. 3. Legal Precedents and Challenges: The use of Section 3 to disqualify a candidate like Trump would be unprecedented in modern times. This means there would likely be significant legal challenges and debates, potentially delaying or complicating the process. 4. Timeframe: The question specifies a resolution date of July 15, 2024. Given the complexities of legal proceedings and the time required for state governments or courts to make and finalize such decisions, the timeframe is relatively short. Considering these factors, while there is a legal basis for potentially removing Trump from ballots under Section 3, the unprecedented nature of such an action, the required legal processes, and the specified timeframe make it challenging to predict with certainty. However, given the political will and legal efforts that could be mobilized, it's not entirely impossible.

question.title: Will 538 Project Biden as the favorite on Friday?
question.body:
This market will resolve to “Yes” if Joe Biden has a higher probability of winning the US presidential election than Donald Trump according to the FiveThirtyEight election forecast for the day of July 19, 2024. This market will resolve to “No” if Donald Trump has a higher probability of winning the US presidential election than Joe Biden according to the FiveThirtyEight election forecast for the day of July 19, 2024. If Biden and Trump have equal odds, this market will resolve 50-50.

The resolution source will be FiveThirtyEight's 2024 presidential election forecast, https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2024-election-forecast/, specifically the numbers indicated by the blue and red trend lines for this market's resolution date. Changes in the methodology by which FiveThirtyEight calculates its figures will have no bearing on the resolution of this market.

This market will resolve according to the datapoints for July 19 as soon as datapoints for July 20 become available. This market may not resolve until the July 20 datapoints are available. If no datapoints for July 19 are available by July 22, 11:59 PM ET, this market will resolve according to the nearest previous figures to July 19.

Please note the resolution refers to the odds of each candidate winning as a number out of 100 reported to the 1 digit mark (eg. "Trump 57 times out of 100"). The listed number of simulations out of 1,000 won by each candidate will NOT be considered.

Given these considerations, it is possible that ISS could recommend voting against Elon Musk's package or Kimbal Musk's re-election if they deem them not in the best interest of shareholders. question.title: Will Biden be declared incapacitated under the 25th Amendment Section 4 before August?
question.body:
Resolves YES if the Vice President and a majority of the Cabinet (or other relevant body) invokes Section 4 of the 25th Amendment to formally declare that "the President is unable to discharge the powers and duties of his office" and cause the Vice President to serve as Acting President, before August 2024 (Eastern time).

The duration of the incapacity does not matter for this question.

Biden exiting the office of the Presidency by death, resignation, etc does not count. Biden invoking section 3 of the 25th amendment does not count.

Context: GOP lawmaker asks Merrick Garland to invoke 25th Amendment to remove Biden from office

metadata.chain_of_thought: To estimate the probability of President Biden being declared incapacitated under the 25th Amendment Section 4 before August 2024, let's analyze the situation: 1. Political Climate and Precedent: Historically, the 25th Amendment has been invoked rarely, and its Section 4, which deals with the incapacitation of the President, has never been invoked. This suggests a high bar for its invocation. 2. Current Political Environment: The question mentions a GOP lawmaker asking Merrick Garland to invoke the 25th Amendment, indicating political tensions. However, such calls are not uncommon in highly polarized political environments and do not necessarily translate into action. 3. Requirements for Invocation: For Section 4 to be invoked, the Vice President and a majority of the Cabinet must agree. This is a high threshold, especially considering the political implications and potential backlash. 4. Presidential Health and Performance: Without specific information on President Biden's health or performance issues that would necessitate such a declaration, it's challenging to assess the likelihood based on this factor alone. However, public discourse and political opposition do not typically suffice for a declaration of incapacitation. 5. Timing: The question specifies before August 2024, which is a relatively short timeframe for such a significant political and constitutional process to unfold. question.title: Will Democrats have a brokered convention in 2024?
question.body: This question resolves as **Yes** if the Democratic Party requires more than one round of voting in its roll call ballot to formally nominate its candidate for the 2024 US presidential election. If only one ballot is required, then this question resolves as **No**.

metadata.chain_of_thought: A brokered convention occurs when no candidate has a majority of delegates after the first round of voting, leading to subsequent rounds of voting to determine the nominee. Historically, brokered conventions have been rare, with the last one occurring in 1952 for the Democrats and 1948 for the Republicans. However, the 2020 Democratic primary saw a large field of candidates, increasing the likelihood of a brokered convention. Although the field for the 2024 Democratic primary is currently smaller, there is still a possibility of a brokered convention if multiple candidates remain competitive. Given the current political landscape and the potential for a competitive primary, I estimate the probability of a brokered convention at 0.25.

question.title: Facing Joe Biden instead of a generic Democrat, will Trump gain at least 3% among Manifold respondents?
question.body:
There are two Manifold polls posted, which both close on July 6.  One of the polls asks Manifold respondents to vote with Joe Biden on a hypothetical ballot, and another asks respondents to vote with a generic Democrat on the hypothetical ballot.

@/SteveSokolowski/1-of-2-given-these-choices-who-woul@/SteveSokolowski/2-of-2-given-these-choices-who-woul 

Public opinion polls consistently show Joe Biden losing to Donald Trump outside the margin of error, but every other Democrat hypothetically surveyed polls ahead or within the margin of error.  Are Manifold respondents representative of the general public?

This market will resolve YES if the percentage of votes for Donald Trump in poll 1 exceeds that in poll 2 by 3% or more when both polls close.

The formula for determining the percentage of votes for Trump is (Trump / (Trump + (the Democrat in the question) + Someone else)).  The answer is YES if this formula for poll 1 - the formula for poll 2 >= 0.03.  Otherwise, it is NO.

The polls and this question will never resolve N/A, and will remain open until the close time no matter what.

question.title: Will Donald Trump be removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment?
question.body:
This question will resolve as "Yes" if, *on* July 15, 2024:

Donald Trump has been officially removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office (President, Senate, House of Representatives) under the grounds of Section 3 of the 14th Amendment.

The removal or block is confirmed through official state government announcements, court decisions, legal documentation, or credible media reports. Speculative reports, opinion pieces, or unofficial announcements will not suffice for resolution.

The question will resolve as "No" if these conditions are not met as of July 15, 2024.

Note: The question does not account for legal battles, appeals, or subsequent reversals that might occur *after* the mentioned date. It strictly pertains to whether Donald Trump has been removed from any state's primary election ballot for a federal office under the specified grounds as of July 15, 2024. If Trump is removed or blocked from a ballot and then reinstated, such that as of July 15th he is not removed or blocked from any ballot, the question resolves negatively.

metadata.chain_of_thought: This question is asking about the possibility of Donald Trump being removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment by July 15, 2024. To assess this probability, we need to consider the current political climate, the legal framework, and the likelihood of such an event occurring within the given timeframe. Section 3 of the 14th Amendment, also known as the Disqualification Clause, states that no person shall be a senator or representative in Congress, or elector of president and vice president, or hold any office, civil or military, under the United States or under any state, who, having previously taken an oath to support the Constitution, has engaged in insurrection or rebellion against the United States, or given aid or comfort to its enemies. Given the current political polarization and the ongoing investigations into Donald Trump's actions, it is possible that some states might attempt to remove him from the ballot under this clause. However, the process of doing so would likely involve lengthy legal battles and would need to be resolved by July 15, 2024, which is a relatively short timeframe. Moreover, the Disqualification Clause has rarely been invoked in the past, and its application to a former president is unprecedented. The legal framework and precedents are not well-established, which adds to the uncertainty. Considering these factors, while it is possible that some states might attempt to remove Trump from the ballot, the likelihood of such an event occurring and being confirmed through official channels by July 15, 2024, is relatively low.

question.title: Will Ted Cruz be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if Ted Cruz is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. All other candidates will resolve as **No**. This question is not restricted to the candidates currently below; other options may be added in the future.

For this question, it is not relevant who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

metadata.chain_of_thought: Ted Cruz has a significant political presence and experience from his 2016 run, but the competitiveness of the Republican field and the evolving political landscape pose challenges. His chances are notable but not guaranteed, making his probability of becoming the nominee less than a clear frontrunner but higher than a long shot.

question.body: For Google DeepMind, this question resolves as **YES** if, by June 30, 2024, they publish a *public* report with the results from an *external* party red-teaming the safety of one of their AI models.

External red-teaming, which involves having external parties test the safety of their models, is a common practice in the field. Given the growing importance of AI safety, it's likely that Google DeepMind would want to demonstrate their commitment to safety by publishing the results of external red-teaming. However, there are a few factors to consider that might reduce the likelihood of this happening. Despite these factors, I believe that the benefits of publishing the results of external red-teaming, including demonstrating a commitment to safety and transparency, outweigh the costs. Additionally, Google DeepMind has a history of publishing research on AI safety, which suggests that they might be willing to publish the results of external red-teaming. Given the time frame of the question, which is roughly a year after the creation date, it's possible that Google DeepMind has had sufficient time to conduct and publish the results of external red-teaming.

question.title: Will OpenAI's ChatGPT be generally available in the European Union on June 30, 2024?
question.body:
The question resolves as **YES** if [ChatGPT](chat.openai.com) is generally available in the EU on June 30, 2024, and **NO** otherwise.

"Generally available" here means that the default state for people in the EU is that they can access it without a VPN (possibly requiring paying for it.) If unavailable in certain EU countries (as was the case in Italy in early 2023), or unavailable to (for example) minors, this will still resolve positively, assuming at least >50% of the population can use it.

"ChatGPT" here refers to the general web interface (not the API) for interacting with GPT models. Still resolves positively if the name or website has changed, as long as OpenAI's service is substantially the same (entering queries to systems based on Large Language Models).

metadata.chain_of_thought: To estimate the probability of both Malta and Slovenia qualifying for the Grand Final in Eurovision 2024, we need to consider their past performances and the overall competitiveness of the contest. Malta has a relatively strong track record in Eurovision, having qualified for the Grand Final in 7 out of the last 10 contests. Slovenia, on the other hand, has been less successful, qualifying for the Grand Final only 3 times in the last 10 contests. However, both countries have shown improvement in recent years, with Malta finishing in the top 10 in 2019 and Slovenia qualifying for the Grand Final in 2022. Given the unpredictability of the contest and the fact that both countries will participate in a Semi-final, I estimate that Malta has a 60% chance of qualifying for the Grand Final, while Slovenia has a 40% chance. Since the question requires both countries to qualify, we need to multiply their individual probabilities, resulting in a combined probability of 0.6 x 0.4 = 0.24.

question.title: Will either Malta or Slovenia qualify for the Grand Final in Eurovision 2024?
question.body: This question will resolve as **Yes** if either Malta or Slovenia participates in a Semi-final and is officially announced by the European Broadcasting Union (EBU) as having qualified for the Eurovision 2024 Grand Final. If neither qualifies, the question will resolve as **No**.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To estimate the probability of either Malta or Slovenia qualifying for the Grand Final in Eurovision 2024, we need to consider their past performances and the general competitiveness of the contest. Malta has a relatively strong track record in Eurovision, with several top 10 finishes in the past decade, including a runner-up finish in 2021. Slovenia, on the other hand, has not had as much success, with only a few top 10 finishes since the introduction of the semi-final system in 2004. However, both countries have a dedicated fan base and can potentially send a strong entry. Given the unpredictability of the contest and the fact that both countries have a chance to send a competitive entry, it's difficult to estimate their chances with high precision. However, based on their past performances, I would argue that Malta has a slightly higher chance of qualifying than Slovenia. Assuming that the qualification rate for the Grand Final is around 50% (10 out of 20 countries qualify from each semi-final), and considering Malta's stronger track record, I would estimate that Malta has around a 60% chance of qualifying, while Slovenia has around a 40% chance. Since the question asks about either Malta or Slovenia qualifying, we need to calculate the probability that at least one of them qualifies. This can be done by subtracting the probability that neither of them qualifies from 1. Assuming independence between the two events, the probability that neither Malta nor Slovenia qualifies is (1 - 0.6) * (1 - 0.4) = 0.24. Therefore, the probability that at least one of them qualifies is 1 - 0.24 = 0.76.

question.title: Will a terrorist act occur in metropolitan France during the 2024 Summer Olympics?
question.body:
The question will resolve as Yes if a terrorist attack in [Metropolitan France](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Metropolitan_France) injures and/or kills at least one person, other than the terrorist(s), between, and inclusive of, the day of the Opening Ceremony (26 July 2024) and the day of the Closing Ceremony (11 August 2024). The question will resolve as No if the above does not happen.

An event will be considered a 'terrorist attack' if it is described as such by any agency of the State of France, or by the French President, Prime Minister, or a member of the Council of Ministers.

metadata.chain_of_thought: Assessing the likelihood of a terrorist act occurring in metropolitan France during the 2024 Summer Olympics involves considering various factors, including historical precedent, current global and regional security conditions, and the specific context of the event. Historically, France has experienced several terrorist attacks in recent years, such as the 2015 Paris attacks and the 2016 Nice truck attack. These incidents highlight the country's vulnerability to such threats. However, it's also important to note that France has significantly enhanced its security measures and counter-terrorism efforts since then. The 2024 Summer Olympics, being a high-profile international event, will undoubtedly attract extensive security coverage. French authorities, in collaboration with international partners, will likely implement robust security protocols to minimize the risk of a terrorist attack. This includes increased surveillance, intelligence gathering, and the deployment of security personnel. Despite these efforts, the threat of terrorism remains a persistent global concern. Given these considerations, while the probability of a terrorist act cannot be ruled out entirely, the enhanced security measures and the French government's experience in managing such risks suggest that the likelihood is lower than it might be under normal circumstances.

question.title: Will both of the following occur: (1) Before July 1, 2024, the ICC issues arrest warrants for listed Israeli leaders; (2) A terrorist act occurs in metropolitan France during the 2024 Summer Olympics?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if both of the following conditions are met:

1. Before July 1, 2024, the International Criminal Court (ICC) issues a warrant of arrest for any of the following Israeli cabinet members:
   * Benjamin Netanyahu (Prime Minister)
   * Yoav Gallant (Defense Minister)
   * Herzi Halevi (IDF Chief of Staff)

2. A terrorist attack occurs in Metropolitan France that injures and/or kills at least one person, other than the terrorist(s), between, and inclusive of, the day of the Opening Ceremony (26 July 2024) and the day of the Closing Ceremony (11 August 2024) of the 2024 Summer Olympics. An event will be considered a 'terrorist attack' if it is described as such by any agency of the State of France, or by the French President, Prime Minister, or a member of the Council of Ministers.

The question will resolve as **No** if one or both of the above conditions are not met.

Condition 1: The ICC issuing arrest warrants for listed Israeli leaders before July 1, 2024. The ICC has been investigating alleged war crimes in the Palestinian territories since 2015, and in 2021, it launched a formal investigation. However, the ICC's process is often slow, and it's unclear whether they will issue warrants for the specified Israeli leaders within the given timeframe. Considering the complexity of the investigation and the potential political implications, I'd estimate the probability of this condition being met at around 0.3. Condition 2: A terrorist attack occurring in metropolitan France during the 2024 Summer Olympics. France has faced several terrorist attacks in recent years, and the Olympics might be a potential target. However, France has also strengthened its security measures, and the Olympics will likely have a significant security presence. Given the uncertainty and the difficulty of predicting terrorist attacks, I'd estimate the probability of this condition being met at around 0.2. To combine these probabilities, I'll use the assumption of independence, which might not be entirely accurate but provides a reasonable estimate. The probability of both conditions being met is the product of the individual probabilities: 0.3 * 0.2 = 0.06.

question.title: Will Joe Biden have an in-person interview/conversation on camera for 45+ minutes, before the end of July 2024?
question.body:
The most recent qualifying interview was Biden's appearance on The Howard Stern Show in April, when Biden answered questions for ~70 minutes. 

If Biden appears in another such in-person interview for at least 45 minutes, this market resolves YES. If no qualifying interview is released before market close at the end of July, this market resolves NO. 

This market does not include press conferences, speeches, rallies, fundraisers, town halls, etc. It can include appearances on a podcast or late night show, or an interview edited into a show like 60 minutes. However, there must be at least 45 minutes of new footage of Biden being interviewed in-person for such appearances to count. A 50 minute video might only feature 20 minutes of video of Biden being interviewed, and so would not count.

For context, Biden's interview with Stephanopoulos in July, his appearance on Jimmy Fallon in February, and his past appearances on 60 minutes have each had less than 30 minutes of video footage of Biden being interviewed. 

You can find a list of Biden's interviews and their transcripts here.

question.title: Will Biden be declared incapacitated under the 25th Amendment Section 4 before August?
question.body:
Resolves YES if the Vice President and a majority of the Cabinet (or other relevant body) invokes Section 4 of the 25th Amendment to formally declare that "the President is unable to discharge the powers and duties of his office" and cause the Vice President to serve as Acting President, before August 2024 (Eastern time).

The duration of the incapacity does not matter for this question.

Biden exiting the office of the Presidency by death, resignation, etc does not count. Biden invoking section 3 of the 25th amendment does not count.

Context: GOP lawmaker asks Merrick Garland to invoke 25th Amendment to remove Biden from office

metadata.chain_of_thought: The question is asking whether President Biden will be declared incapacitated under the 25th Amendment Section 4 before August 2024. This requires the Vice President and a majority of the Cabinet to invoke Section 4, declaring that the President is unable to discharge the powers and duties of his office. To assess the likelihood of this event, let's consider the following factors: 1. Precedent: The 25th Amendment has been invoked only a handful of times in U.S. history, and never for the purpose of declaring a President incapacitated. This suggests that such an event is rare and typically requires extraordinary circumstances. 2. Current political climate: The fact that a GOP lawmaker has asked Merrick Garland to invoke the 25th Amendment to remove Biden from office indicates that there is some political pressure to do so. However, it's essential to note that this is likely a partisan move, and the Vice President and Cabinet may not be inclined to take such a drastic step without clear evidence of incapacitation. 3. Biden's health: While President Biden's age and health have been subjects of public concern, there is no concrete evidence to suggest that he is currently incapacitated or unable to perform his duties. 4. Procedural hurdles: Invoking Section 4 of the 25th Amendment requires a formal declaration by the Vice President and a majority of the Cabinet. This is a high bar to clear, especially given the potential political fallout and the need for bipartisan cooperation. Considering these factors, it appears that the likelihood of President Biden being declared incapacitated under the 25th Amendment Section 4 before August 2024 is low. While there may be some political pressure to do so, the procedural hurdles and lack of clear evidence of incapacitation make it unlikely that the Vice President and Cabinet will take such a drastic step.

question.title: Will at least 20 House/Senate Democrats sign a public letter opposing the plan to virtually nominate Biden early?
question.body:
Context from Politico:

Dozens of House Democrats are organizing a plan to speak out against their own party’s effort to seal President Joe Biden’s nomination sooner than originally planned, which they argue stifles the intense ongoing debate about his candidacy, according to a lawmaker involved in the effort.

A drafted letter, circulated by Rep. Jared Huffman (D-Calif.) and obtained by POLITICO, offers the first public signal from Democrats since the weekend’s attempted assassination on former President Donald Trump that scores of their own members remain deeply unsettled about the future of Biden’s candidacy.

“It’s a really bad move by the DNC. Somebody thinks it’s a clever way to lock down debate and I guess by dint of sheer force, achieve unity, but it doesn’t work that way,” Huffman said in an interview. He declined to confirm the existence of a letter.

This market resolves YES if a public letter opposing the early nomination plan is signed by at least 20 House Members or Senators who caucus with the Democratic Party before market close at the end of Sunday, July 21st. 

Multiple such letters with a combined total of 20 lawmaker's signatures would also be sufficient to resolve this market to YES. 

If these criteria are not met by market close, this market resolves NO.

The fact that a drafted letter is being circulated and that Rep. Jared Huffman is quoted as being strongly opposed to the plan suggests that there is a organized effort to speak out against it. Additionally, the fact that the letter is being circulated and that Huffman is willing to speak publicly about his opposition suggests that the effort is gaining traction. However, it is unclear how many Democrats will ultimately sign the letter, and it is possible that some may be hesitant to publicly oppose the party's plan. Nevertheless, based on the information provided, it seems likely that at least 20 House/Senate Democrats will sign a public letter opposing the plan.

question.title: Will Biden be declared incapacitated under the 25th Amendment Section 4 before August?
question.body:

Biden exiting the office of the Presidency by death, resignation, etc does not count. Biden invoking section 3 of the 25th amendment does not count.

question.title: Will Democrats have a brokered convention in 2024?
question.body: This question resolves as **Yes** if the Democratic Party requires more than one round of voting in its roll call ballot to formally nominate its candidate for the 2024 US presidential election. If only one ballot is required, then this question resolves as **No**.

metadata.chain_of_thought: The question is asking about the likelihood of a brokered convention for the Democratic Party in the 2024 US presidential election. A brokered convention occurs when no candidate receives a majority of the delegates' votes in the first round of voting, requiring multiple rounds of voting to determine the nominee. Historically, brokered conventions are rare, and the Democratic Party has only had a few instances of multiple rounds of voting in recent decades. However, the 2024 election is still over a year away, and the field of candidates has not yet been finalized. Additionally, the Democratic Party has implemented rules changes aimed at reducing the likelihood of a brokered convention, such as the use of proportional allocation of delegates in primaries and caucuses. While it is difficult to predict with certainty, the historical rarity of brokered conventions and the party's efforts to prevent them suggest that the likelihood of a brokered convention in 2024 is relatively low.

question.title: Will at least 20 House/Senate Democrats sign a public letter opposing the plan to virtually nominate Biden early?
question.body:
Context from Politico:

Dozens of House Democrats are organizing a plan to speak out against their own party’s effort to seal President Joe Biden’s nomination sooner than originally planned, which they argue stifles the intense ongoing debate about his candidacy, according to a lawmaker involved in the effort.

A drafted letter, circulated by Rep. Jared Huffman (D-Calif.) and obtained by POLITICO, offers the first public signal from Democrats since the weekend’s attempted assassination on former President Donald Trump that scores of their own members remain deeply unsettled about the future of Biden’s candidacy.

“It’s a really bad move by the DNC. Somebody thinks it’s a clever way to lock down debate and I guess by dint of sheer force, achieve unity, but it doesn’t work that way,” Huffman said in an interview. He declined to confirm the existence of a letter.

If Biden and Trump have equal odds, it will resolve 50-50. The resolution source will be FiveThirtyEight's 2024 presidential election forecast, specifically the numbers indicated by the blue and red trend lines for July 19. If no datapoints for July 19 are available by July 22, 11:59 PM ET, it will resolve according to the nearest previous figures.

A positive value means a Trump lead, while a negative value means Biden is leading. For example, a reported value of 2.4 would indicate Trump is 2.4 points ahead of Biden.

question.title: Will the ID political group hold the most seats after the 2024 European Parliamentary Elections?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if the ID political group holds the most seats after the 2024 European Parliament elections. It will resolve as **No** for all other political groups. If two groups are tied for seats, both sub-questions will resolve as **Yes**.

This question resolves on the basis of [official statements by the European Parliament](https://www.europarl.europa.eu/portal/en) or credible media reports.

metadata.chain_of_thought: The ID political group, also known as Identity and Democracy, is a right-wing populist political group in the European Parliament. To estimate the probability of the ID political group holding the most seats after the 2024 European Parliamentary Elections, we need to consider the current political landscape and trends in the European Union. As of the 2019 European Parliament election, the ID political group held 73 seats, which was the fifth-largest group in the parliament. The largest group was the European People's Party (EPP) with 182 seats, followed by the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats (S&D) with 154 seats. To become the largest group, the ID political group would need to significantly increase its seat count, which is uncertain given the current political climate. While populist and nationalist movements have gained traction in some EU member states, the ID political group still faces strong competition from established parties and groups. Moreover, the European Parliament elections are often characterized by a high degree of fragmentation, with many national parties and groups competing for seats. This fragmentation makes it challenging for any single group to dominate the parliament. Given these factors, I estimate the probability of the ID political group holding the most seats after the 2024 European Parliamentary Elections as relatively low.

question.title: Facing Joe Biden instead of a generic Democrat, will Trump gain at least 3% among Manifold respondents?
question.body:
There are two Manifold polls posted, which both close on July 6.  One of the polls asks Manifold respondents to vote with Joe Biden on a hypothetical ballot, and another asks respondents to vote with a generic Democrat on the hypothetical ballot.

@/SteveSokolowski/1-of-2-given-these-choices-who-woul@/SteveSokolowski/2-of-2-given-these-choices-who-woul 

Public opinion polls consistently show Joe Biden losing to Donald Trump outside the margin of error, but every other Democrat hypothetically surveyed polls ahead or within the margin of error.  Are Manifold respondents representative of the general public?

This market will resolve YES if the percentage of votes for Donald Trump in poll 1 exceeds that in poll 2 by 3% or more when both polls close.

The formula for determining the percentage of votes for Trump is (Trump / (Trump + (the Democrat in the question) + Someone else)).  The answer is YES if this formula for poll 1 - the formula for poll 2 >= 0.03.  Otherwise, it is NO.

The polls and this question will never resolve N/A, and will remain open until the close time no matter what.

Public opinion polls have consistently shown that Biden loses to Trump outside the margin of error, but other Democrats polled ahead or within the margin of error. question.title: Will a group of at least 5 named Dem House Members or US Senators pressure Biden to drop out before July 20th?
question.body:
Politico reports:

Two safe-seat members have already publicly urged Biden out. Two of the most endangered Democrats told local news outlets they’ve already written off Biden’s chances to win in November.

Behind the scenes, things are even more frenzied. There are multiple drafts of letters circulating among House Democrats and at least one would call on Biden to end his campaign, according to five people familiar with the efforts.

This market resolves YES if a group of at least five named Democratic Party US House Members/US Senators work together to ask Joe Biden to consider ending his 2024 re-election campaign, or to urge him to do so, before Saturday July 20th (Pacific Time).

This could be by signing a letter like what is reported above, but it could also be in another form such as a group speaking with Biden in person and collectively asking him to drop out.

This market requires that all five individuals be part of the same group message. Five people separately telling reporters they think Biden should drop out is not sufficient for a YES resolution.

Reports of any number of unnamed democrats writing to Biden and asking him to step aside will not satisfy this market's criteria unless at least 5 qualifying names are later made public before this market's end date. In any ambiguous cases where such names are reported but not confirmed beyond a reasonable doubt, this market will err towards resolving NO. 

If these criteria are not met before July 20th, this market resolves NO.

One asks respondents to vote with Joe Biden on a hypothetical ballot, and another with a generic Democrat. This will resolve YES if the percentage of votes for Trump in the Biden poll exceeds the generic Democrat poll by 3% or more. The formula used is (Trump / (Trump + the Democrat + Someone else)) for each poll, and the difference must be >= 0.03 for a YES resolution.

(b) A group of at least 5 named Democratic House Members or Senators pressure Biden to drop out before July 20th: This resolves YES if at least five named Democratic Party US House Members/US Senators work together to ask Biden to consider ending his 2024 re-election campaign before July 20th, either by signing a letter or another form of collective request. All five must be part of the same group message. Reports of unnamed Democrats are insufficient unless names are made public before the end date.

For event (a), we need to analyze the polling data from Manifold. However, without access to the specific polling data or historical trends, it's challenging to make an informed estimate. Nevertheless, it's reasonable to assume that the difference in Trump's performance between the two polls might be relatively small, given that the polls are identical except for the opponent. While there might be some discontent among Democrats regarding Biden's candidacy, it's unlikely that a group of prominent lawmakers would publicly call for him to drop out, especially given the potential backlash and the fact that the Democratic primary process is still ongoing. Considering both events, I would estimate the probability of either event occurring as follows: Probability: 0.25. metadata.chain_of_thought: Eurovision qualification is notoriously hard to predict, but we can look at historical trends to inform our forecast. Czechia has qualified for the Grand Final 5 out of the last 7 years, with a relatively consistent level of quality in their entries. San Marino, on the other hand, has only qualified twice in the last 7 years, but has shown some improvement in recent years. I will assume that the probability of Czechia qualifying is around 60% and San Marino qualifying is around 30%. Since the question only requires one of them to qualify, we can use the formula for the probability of at least one of two events occurring: P(A or B) = P(A) + P(B) - P(A and B). Assuming independence, P(A and B) = P(A) * P(B). So, P(Czechia or San Marino qualifying) = 0.6 + 0.3 - (0.6 * 0.3) = 0.72.

question.title: Will Donald Trump be removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment?
question.body:
This question will resolve as "Yes" if, *on* July 15, 2024:

Donald Trump has been officially removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office (President, Senate, House of Representatives) under the grounds of Section 3 of the 14th Amendment.

The removal or block is confirmed through official state government announcements, court decisions, legal documentation, or credible media reports. Speculative reports, opinion pieces, or unofficial announcements will not suffice for resolution.

The question will resolve as "No" if these conditions are not met as of July 15, 2024.

Note: The question does not account for legal battles, appeals, or subsequent reversals that might occur *after* the mentioned date. It strictly pertains to whether Donald Trump has been removed from any state's primary election ballot for a federal office under the specified grounds as of July 15, 2024. If Trump is removed or blocked from a ballot and then reinstated, such that as of July 15th he is not removed or blocked from any ballot, the question resolves negatively.

metadata.chain_of_thought: The question revolves around whether Donald Trump will be removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment by July 15, 2024. Section 3 of the 14th Amendment, also known as the Disqualification Clause, prohibits individuals who have engaged in insurrection or rebellion against the United States from holding federal office. The clause has been invoked in discussions about Trump's eligibility due to his role in the January 6, 2021, storming of the U.S. Capitol. To assess the probability of Trump being removed or blocked under this clause, several factors come into play: 1. Legal and Political Challenges: The application of Section 3 of the 14th Amendment to Trump's situation is unprecedented in modern times and would likely face significant legal and political challenges. Any attempt to remove him from the ballot would need to navigate through state and possibly federal courts, which could be time-consuming and contentious. 2. State-Level Actions: The question's resolution depends on actions taken at the state level. Given the political polarization in the U.S., it's plausible that some states might attempt to invoke Section 3 against Trump, but the success of such attempts is uncertain. 3. Timeframe: The question specifies that the removal or block must be confirmed by July 15, 2024. Given the potential for legal challenges and the time required for court proceedings, the timeframe is relatively tight. 4. Precedent and Legal Interpretation: The legal interpretation of Section 3 and its application to Trump's situation is not straightforward. Courts would need to establish a precedent for its use in this context, which adds to the uncertainty. Given these considerations, while there is a plausible scenario in which Trump could be removed or blocked from a state's primary election ballot under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment, the legal, political, and temporal hurdles suggest that the likelihood is not high.

question.body: This question will resolve to "Yes" if, following the 2024 European Parliament elections, the Fidesz-KDNP alliance secures more seats than any other single party or coalition, thereby maintaining the highest number of Hungarian seats in the European Parliament, according to credible sources.

metadata.chain_of_thought: Fidesz-KDNP has been the dominant political force in Hungary since 2010, and it has consistently performed well in European Parliament elections.
